Project Description  The Project continues the support of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  for  the  rehabilitation  and  upgrading  of  irrigation  and 
drainage  infrastructure  and  capacity  development  for  water 
management. The Project is structured as a sector loan project. It 
will involve two areas of the country: (i) the Zarafshan River Basin, 
and (ii) the Fergana Valley. The Project will (i) rehabilitate and 
upgrade pumping stations, (ii) rehabilitate and upgrade inter-farm 
irrigation and drainage canals and structures, and (iii) improve 
inter-farm water management through state water agencies and 
on-farm management through water users’ associations (WUAs). 
The  primary  aim  is  sustained  and  increased  agriculture 
productivity. 
   
Rationale  Agriculture remains a key sector of the economy and the main 
source  of  livelihood  for  the  rural  population.  Irrigation  and 
drainage are key factors in agriculture, and critical to productivity, 
competitiveness, and environmental management. However, the 
infrastructure  is  deteriorating  rapidly.  Pump  stations  are  losing 
capacity and the inter-farm facilities are contributing to substantial 
water  losses.  Rehabilitation  of  pump  stations  and  inter-farm 
canals is essential to avoid the partial or complete collapse of 
irrigation  systems,  with  consequent  losses  in  agricultural 
production and farm incomes. To realize the full benefit of the 
infrastructure  rehabilitation  and  provide  for  more  effective 
operation and maintenance in the future, it is essential to improve 
water management at the basin, inter-farm canal, and on-farm 
levels.  
 
The rehabilitation needs are substantial, but the level of funding 
available  from  the  Government  and  development  partners  is 
limited. This means prioritizing investments. The Government has 
requested the focus to be on rehabilitation of pump stations and 
related  inter-farm  canals,  together  with  improved  water 
management from the river basin to the WUA level.

ii   
Impact and Outcome  The  Project’s  expected  impact  is  sustained  and  increased 
agriculture production and productivity. The expected outcome is 
irrigation  systems  fully  functional  and  operated  in  an  efficient 
manner. 
   
Project Investment Plan   The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $148.0 million, 
including  taxes  and  duties,  physical  and  price  contingencies, 
interest charges during implementation, and commitment charges. 
   
Financing Plan  ADB will provide a blend of two loans totaling $100 million: (i) $85 
million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources (OCR), and (ii) an 
Asian  Development  Fund  (ADF)  loan  in  various  currencies 
equivalent to Special Drawing Rights 10.042 million (estimated at 
$15 million). The OCR loan will have a 26-year term, including a 
grace period of 6 years, an interest rate determined in accordance 
with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending 
facility,  a  commitment  charge  of  0.15%  per  annum,  and  such 
other  terms  and  conditions  to  be  set  forth  in  the  draft  Loan 
Agreement. The ADF loan will have a 32-year term, including a 
grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1% yearly during the 
grace period and 1.5% yearly after that, and such other terms and 
conditions as are set forth in the draft Loan Agreement. 
   
Period of Utilization  Until 30 June 2015 
   
Estimated Project  31 December 2014 
Completion Date 
   
Executing Agency  Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources (MAWR) 
   
Implementation  The Project will be implemented over 6 years starting in early 
Arrangements  2009. A project steering committee will guide policy and strategic 
  direction. A project director will be appointed by MAWR. A project 
  management office will be established within MAWR in Tashkent 
to  manage  day-to-day  implementation  activities.  Project 
implementation units will be established in Samarkand city in the 
Zarafshan River Basin and Fergana city in the Fergana Valley. A 
full-time project manager, who will be acceptable to ADB, will 
manage the project management office, while deputy managers 
will oversee each project implementation units. 
   
Procurement  The Project will finance the procurement of equipment, civil works, 
and consulting services. All procurement will be in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time 
to time).

iii
Consulting Services  The  Project  will  provide  154  person-months  of  international 
consulting services and 490 person-months of national consulting 
services. A service contract for WUA training will be executed. 
The  consultants  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from 
time to time), using the quality- and cost-based selection method 
for a firm in addition to individual consultant engagements. 
   
Project Benefits and  Project  benefits  include  (i)  reduced  production  losses, 
Beneficiaries  (ii) increased energy efficiency, (iii) improved water management, 
(iv)  decreased  land  degradation  caused  by  soil  salinity  and 
waterlogging,  (v)  increased  irrigation  efficiency,  (vi)  enhanced 
farm productivity through increased yields and cropping intensity, 
and (vii) increased rural livelihoods. 
 
The Project has an overall economic internal rate of return of 
15.5%. Two core subprojects analyzed during preparation of the 
Project had economic internal rate of return of 15.4% and 13.4%. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  Major risks include ineffective project management, inadequate 
system  operation  and  maintenance  and  management,  and 
implementation  delays  caused  by  cumbersome  internal 
Government  procedures.  Other  risks  include  macroeconomic 
shocks and commodity price instability.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans 
to the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Water Resources Management Sector Project. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
2.  The  Water  Resources  Management  Sector  Project  was  prepared  by  a  project 
preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) approved in 2008.1 This document is based on the 
consultants’ studies, surveys, and reports; the findings of Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
missions;  and  discussion  with  government  agencies,  stakeholders,  beneficiaries,  and 
development partners. A problem tree analysis is in Appendix 1 and a project design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 2. 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
3.  Uzbekistan recorded per capita gross domestic product (GDP) of $814 in 2007. GDP 
growth rates increased from 3.8% in 2000 to 4.4% in 2003, to an annual average of over 7% 
during 2004–20062 and 9.5% in 2007.3 Agriculture growth fluctuated from 3.2% in 2000, to 
10.1% in 2004 to 6.1% in 2007. The share of agriculture in GDP declined from 30.1% in 2000 to 
24.1% in 2006. Despite this decline, agriculture remains an important sector, accounting for 
70% of domestic trade, 35%–40% of industrial output (about 7.8% of GDP), 25% of export 
earnings, and 33% of employment. While poverty declined from 27.5% in 2001 to 25.8% in 
2005, poverty in rural areas remains high. About 64% of the population lives in rural areas. 
Detailed analysis of the sector is provided in Appendix 3.  
 
4.  Uzbekistan is an arid country. It relies on the Amu Darya and Syr Darya rivers and their 
tributaries to support irrigated agriculture. Water supply varies on a seasonal basis, with many 
areas  not  having  enough.  Irrigated  agriculture  accounts  for  over  90%  of  all  agricultural 
production  and  consumes  88%  of  all  water  resources—57  cubic  kilometers  annually.  The 
development and management of irrigation and drainage infrastructure and improved water 
management are fundamental actions to ensure that agriculture continues to develop over the 
medium term.  
 
5.  Uzbekistan has about 4.3 million hectares (ha) under irrigation. The irrigation network 
includes inter-farm and on-farm systems.4 Irrigation primarily relies on surface water, which is 
distributed by gravity and pumps. The network includes (i) 30,000 kilometers (km) of main and 
inter-farm canals, with over 33,000 hydraulic structures; (ii) 1,500 pumping facilities, with almost 
5,000  pumps  that  supply  water  to  2  million  ha;  (iii)  175,000  km  of  on-farm  canals  and 
conveyance structures; (iv) 40,000 km of on-farm horizontal drains and 4,300 vertical drains; (v) 
120,000 km of drainage ditches; and (vi) 15,000 km of large drainage collectors.

6.  The farming structure has evolved since independence. Shirkat farms were created from 
Soviet collective farms, but all were transformed into private farms by the end of 2007. There 
are now about 190,000 private farms with an average area of 26 ha. Shirkat farm operations are 
still controlled by the Government through the quota and state order system, especially in the 
case of the strategic commodities of cotton and wheat. These also receive credit and inputs 
from the Government. Almost 1.8 million people are employed on private farms. These farms 
produce 32% of agricultural output, including 86% of raw cotton and 73% of grain crops. The 
state order system has been relaxed over the decade, and farms can now sell 50% of their 
wheat and cotton production to the open market. This is having a good impact on productivity 
and the system will continue to be made more flexible. Cotton comprises 41% of the irrigated 
area and wheat comprises 42%. The production system remains inefficient, and excess water 
use  contributes  to  salinity  and  land  degradation.  The  cropping  pattern  does  not  allow  for 
periodic fallowing of land or rotation with fodder or other crops to replenish soil nutrients and 
absorb salts. Dekhan farms are small inheritable household plot (0.15–0.35 hectares) free from 
Government  quotas  for  crop  selection  and  marketing.  Their  land  use  rights  have  been 
transferred  to  private  individuals.  This  allows  for  secure  possession,  inheritance,  and  free 
cropping patterns. There are 4 million–5 million small dekhan farms. They produce nearly one 
fifth of the country’s grains and almost all of the horticulture output. They also provide important 
cash flow to farmers. 
 
7.  Cotton remains the priority crop, and Uzbekistan is the world’s sixth largest producer. 
The Government plans to increase the domestic use of cotton fibers and raise value added 
through the development of a better textile industry. Wheat is the other priority crop, with self-
sufficiency achieved in 1997. Because of fluctuations in food prices and the current world food 
security situation, the Government intends to maintain its policy of wheat self-sufficiency.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
8.  Irrigation and Drainage Needs. Although the infrastructure was well built, its current 
condition  is  poor,  primarily  because  of  lack  of  investment  and  inadequate  maintenance. 
Government investment in agriculture as a whole has declined from 27% of all investments in 
1991 to 8% in 2001. From 1995 to 2002, government funding for the water network dropped 
from 3% to under 2% of GDP. Expenditure in operation and maintenance (O&M) has slowed by 
one third. It is estimated that deferred capital and O&M expenditures amounts to 40% of asset 
value. 
 
9.  The irrigation and drainage system needs substantial rehabilitation and upgrading (R&U) 
and water losses are high. Some structures are at risk of total failure, which would cause 
agricultural  production  and  farm  incomes  to  decline  dramatically.  Investment  is  needed  in 
several areas: (i) total reconstruction of 32% of the main and inter-farm canals; (ii) repair of 24% 
of the main and inter-farm canal network; (iii) rebuilding of 42% of the on-farm irrigation network, 
and repair of 17%; (iv) replacement and modernization of mechanical equipment of 18 of the 
42 large intake structures, and reconstruction of 5; (v) 16 of the 27 inspected reservoirs are 
nonfunctional or threatened with sedimentation; (vi) 19,000 km of on-farm drainage need de-
silting,  and  11,500  km  of  open  and  subsurface  drains  need  reconstruction  or  repair;  and 
(vii) only 50% of the subsurface horizontal drainage systems are operational. The limited use of 
water-efficient irrigation technologies means an unneeded 10%–15% of water supply is required 
for irrigation. The high water table and use of drainage water for irrigation increases salinity and 
requires substantial water for leaching. Sustained investment in R&U and better O&M will 
prevent further deterioration and ensure stability in the farming system.

3 
 
10.  Pumped irrigation and drainage is ubiquitous and poses special challenges. It includes 
the three massive irrigation pump cascade systems from the Amu Darya (which includes the 
Amu  Bukhara,  Karshi,  and  Amu  Zhang  systems).  Together,  these  systems  irrigate  over 
800,000 ha of land. Amu Zhang is currently being rehabilitated under a project financed by ADB. 
The other two large cascades also need urgent rehabilitation.5 Smaller pump-based irrigation 
facilities are located throughout the gravity irrigation networks, with schemes of 10,000 ha of 
farmland commonly reliant on pumps. Almost all pumps are operating beyond their design life, 
and their maintenance and repair has been poor. Pumps are starting to fail or threatening to do 
so. Of the 76 very large pumping facilities with capacities greater than 100 cubic meters per 
second (m3/sec), 60 require immediate rehabilitation. In addition, 400 of the 1,000 smaller 
pumped  systems,  with  capacities  less  than  10  m3/sec,  need  immediate  rehabilitation  or 
replacement. Pumped irrigation absorbs 70% of the annual O&M budget of the Ministry of 
Agriculture and Water Resources (MAWR). It consumes 20% of Uzbekistan’s electricity, and the 
outdated equipment consumes 20%–25% more electricity than modern equipment. Substantial 
investment is needed to convert the pumped system into efficient and cost-effective operations. 
The efficiency of smaller pumped systems can be improved through new technology, more 
demand-responsive operating regimes, and improved irrigation techniques. 
 
11.  The total land area of the country is 18 million ha, of which 25% is arable land and 
largely irrigated. The degraded state of irrigation and drainage infrastructure, combined with 
poor water management, result in low water use efficiency and agricultural productivity. Average 
water withdrawal for irrigation is 14,000 cubic meters (m3) per ha, compared with 9,000 m3 per 
ha to 10,000 m3 per ha in countries with similar climates. Irrigation efficiency nationwide is only 
about 40% resulting in wasted water, overloaded drainage systems, environmental degradation, 
and worsening land salinization. MAWR estimates that more than 20,000 ha of land goes out of 
production each year because of salinity. The salinity affects cotton yields, which decline 20%–
30%  on  slightly  salinized  land,  but  up  to  80%  on  highly  salinized  land.  Some  degree  of 
salinization and waterlogging affects 47% of all irrigated land. Productivity in irrigated agriculture 
dropped by 15% in the immediate post-Soviet era. Although recovering slowly, much more work 
is required to improve agricultural productivity. Yields are low at 2.25 tons per ha (t/ha) in the 
case of cotton and 4.2 t/ha for wheat.  
 
12.  Institutional Framework and Management of Irrigation and Drainage. The legal and 
regulatory framework for irrigation and drainage is derived from the Law on Water and Water 
Use, 1993. This addresses water rights and allocation, O&M of irrigation and drainage systems, 
and resolution of water disputes. Other decrees and laws support the establishment of the 
institutions responsible for water resources and irrigation and drainage. A generally sound 
framework for water management and irrigation is in place, but additional supporting legislation 
and revisions to existing laws are under preparation to define more clearly and establish the 
rights and roles of water users’ associations (WUAs) within the irrigation sector.6 
 
13.  The total runoff for water resources generated in Uzbekistan is about 11.5 m3 per year 
while the total demand for irrigation is about 57 m3, with the balance coming from upstream 
countries via the Syr Darya and Amu Darya rivers. In 1992, the Central Asian republics7

14.  MAWR has overall responsibility for water resources. Within MAWR, the Directorate for 
Water Management (DWM) is the primary organization responsible for the development, O&M, 
and management of irrigation and drainage infrastructure. DWM was reorganized in 2003 from 
a provincial and district administrative basis to a water basin set-up in which irrigation and 
drainage are managed by basin irrigation system administrations (BISAs) under DWM.9 The 
territory of each BISA is organized into main canal administrations (MCAs) and irrigation system 
administrations  (ISAs).  Although  the  reorganization  into  BISAs  was  an  improvement  for 
management  of  water  resources  and  irrigation,  BISAs  need  improved  irrigation  and  water 
management  procedures  and  practices  to  manage  water  more  effectively.  Improved 
coordination and clarification of responsibilities among BISAs, MCAs, ISAs, and WUAs would 
also improve water management efficiency. Capacity building to improve the technical skills of 
the BISAs, MCAs, and ISAs for irrigation, drainage, and water management must complement 
any inter-farm investment in infrastructure to help realize its full potential. 
 
15.  Water Users’ Associations. With the conversion of the shirkats to private farms, the 
former  state-supported  O&M  and  management  of  the  on-farm  irrigation  and  drainage 
infrastructure is no longer available. By law, WUAs have the responsibility to operate the on-
farm system and allocate water to farmers, yet the experience with WUAs in Uzbekistan is still 
developing. Although WUAs have been established, no institutionalized program within MAWR 
exists to provide training, equipment, or other resources to support their development. Their 
sizes and responsibilities also vary, depending on the type and complexity of the system. 
Financial sustainability is difficult since membership fees are low, as is the rate of collection 
from farmers. The WUAs also have limited options in their ability to extract payment. The Swiss 
Agency  for  Development  and  Cooperation  (SDC)  has  the  most  experience  in  supporting 
programs that provide training for WUAs and has ongoing programs for WUA training and water 
management in Fergana Valley.10 This program has been implemented through a joint venture 
of the International Water Management Institute (IWMI) and the Interstate Commission for 
Water  Coordination,  Scientific  Information  Center  (ICWC  SIC).  The  approach  importantly 
includes organizing the WUAs based on hydrologic boundaries consistent with best practice. 
The program has significantly improved WUA performance for water management and system 
O&M, and provides experience from which to scale up a broader training effort. 
 
16.  On-farm water management is under the supervision of the WUAs where additional 
training is needed. Efficiency improvements can be achieved through better coordination of ISA 
staff operating the inter-farm systems and WUA staff operating on-farm systems to optimize 
water deliveries. In pump systems, which have greater flexibility and can be more demand-
responsive, better communication and coordination between WUAs and ISA staff could yield

17.  Strategic Sector Work. During preparation of the Project, a draft Medium-Term Sector 
Strategy and Investment Plan was prepared for irrigation, drainage, and water resources in 
discussion with the Government (Supplementary Appendix A). The strategy is derived primarily 
from the substantial policy work that has already been conducted in Uzbekistan for irrigation, 
drainage and water resources. The strategy focuses on maximizing returns and increasing the 
productivity of water use. Essential to this strategy is improved water use efficiency to be 
achieved in part through targeted R&U investment of the inter-farm irrigation system. Many 
pump schemes are currently operating very inefficiently and have effectively exceeded their 
design life. The failure of the pumps will result in catastrophic agricultural productivity losses,

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Sector Investment Approach 
 
26.  The Project will finance investments in the irrigation and drainage sector, especially 
pumped  irrigation  systems.  As  a  part  of  its  sector  investment  plan,  the  Government  has 
identified a list of priority projects throughout the country and has requested ADB to work in the 
Fergana Valley and Zarafshan River Basin.19 The Fergana Valley is a strategic priority as it is 
densely  populated  and  contributes  significantly  to  GDP.  It  is  a  highly  productive  region, 
containing  21%  of  the  irrigated  area  (910,000  ha)  but  providing  35%  of  all  agricultural 
production. About 45% of the irrigated area is served by pump irrigation. The Zarafshan River 
flows in from Tajikistan, and the associated irrigation system (575,000 ha) supports the second 
most important agricultural center in the country. About 30% of the area is served by pump

27.  Narpay Core Subproject. The Narpay pump system is located in Narpay District in 
northwest Samarkand Province. The area has a continental climate with an average annual 
temperature of 15° centigrade and low rainfall (271 millimeters [mm]), most of which occurs 
during winter. The command area (8,206 ha) has sierozems (gray desert soils) characterized by 
low organic content with moderate productivity potential. The average farm size is about 27 ha; 
cotton (57%) and wheat (30%) are the main crops and fodder vegetables, melons, and orchard 
and vineyards are grown on a smaller scale. The pumping plant and irrigation system receive 
water from the Narpay primary canal, fed by the Zarafshan River. They were established in the 
early 1970s and have undergone subsequent modification, including the addition of secondary 
pumps  with  new  irrigated  area.  The  primary  pumping  plant  has  only  six  of  eight  pumps 
operational and their capacity is only about 75% of their design. This situation—coupled with the 
unreliability of the six remaining pumps—results in frequent partial shutdowns and seriously 
limits the water available for irrigation, particularly during peak demand for the cotton crop. The 
inter-farm canal system, which distributes water from the pumps, is in fair condition, yet portions 
exist  where  repair  and/or  replacement  of  the  concrete  lining  is  required;  existing  control 
structures  need  repair  and/or  replacement;  and  a  number  of  additional  control  and 
measurement structures are required. The reduced and unreliable pumping plant output, along 
with efficiency constraints of the distribution network, result in cotton yields considerably below 
the average for the whole of Narpay District. In the absence of urgent R&U, the productivity of 
the Narpay system will continue to decline and is in danger of partial or total collapse. 
 
28.  Besharyk  Core  Subproject.  The  Besharyk  pump  irrigation  scheme  is  located  in 
Besharyk District of Fergana Province between the Syr Darya River to the north and Besharyk 
town to the south. The semiarid area has an average annual air temperature of 15° centigrade 
and very low rainfall (128 mm), with most during the winter months. The command area is about 
8,400 ha and has typical (34%) and light (36%) sierozem soils with low organic content and 
moderate production potential. Average farm size is about 32 ha in size; cotton (48%) and 
wheat (36%) are the main crops, with lesser amounts of maize, vegetables, orchard, and 
perennial fodder crops. The pumping plant takes water directly from the Syr Darya River and 
was established in 1978. Both the capacity and the level of reliability have declined significantly. 
The plant was designed with 10 pumps, eight for irrigation and two to supply water to extensive 
fishponds in the area. During the past seven seasons, only four pumps have been operating 
reliably, seriously limiting irrigation supplies. Crop production in the subproject area is also 
limited by dysfunctional inter-farm and on-farm drains, the resultant high water tables, and 
associated  increases  in  soil  salinity.  The  pumping  plant,  associated  inter-farm  distribution 
system, and the drainage network all require considerable R&U to prevent the possible partial or 
total collapse of the system. The inter-farm distribution network also needs to be expanded and 
rationalized to capture the full benefits associated with the production potential of the area.

B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
29.  The  impact  of  the  Project  is  sustained  and  increased  agriculture  production  and 
productivity. The Project’s outcome is irrigation and drainage systems that are fully functional 
and operated efficiently. 
 
C.  Components and Outputs 
 
30.  The Project will finance investments in three areas: (i) R&U of irrigation and drainage 
infrastructure, (ii) improved water resources management, and (iii) project management. 
 
  1.  Rehabilitation and Upgrading of Irrigation and Drainage Infrastructure 
 
31.  Project  investments  will  focus  on  pumping  facilities;  gravity  head-works;  inter-farm 
distribution canals and structures; and inter-farm and on-farm drainage to increase the reliability 
of irrigation supplies, improve water distribution, and reduce soil degradation. The R&U of 
pumping facilities and replacement of pumps with more efficient equipment will result in energy 
savings. Indicative types of R&U include (i) pumping stations comprising replacement and/or 
repair of intake works, including bulkhead gates and trash racks; replacement of pumps and 
motors;  upgrading  electrical  control  works;  replacement  of  problematic  and/or  unreliable 
reaches  of the  rising mains;  replacement  of  control  valves;  provision  of  appropriate  surge 
protection systems; and repair or replacement of auxiliary works such as floor drains, overhead 
cranes, and ventilation systems; (ii) improving either major or minor surface water intakes for 
both pump and gravity systems to provide greater capture efficiencies and improved control; (iii) 
improving control structures and gauging stations on inter-farm canals consistent with enhanced 
water  management  targets;  (iv)  upgrading  and/or  replacing  gated  outlets  to  on-farm  canal 
outlets from the inter-farm canal and providing a means for measuring the discharge at each 
outlet point; (v) providing necessary rationalization of both alignment and grade of the inter-farm 
canals; (vi) providing adequate cross drainage treatment for the inter-farm canals; (vii) providing 
auxiliary facilities associated with the inter-farm canals such as vehicle and pedestrian bridges 
and canal access for non-irrigation purposes; and (viii) agricultural drainage facilities, especially 
in subproject areas affected by high water table and/or levels of soil salinity.20  
 
  2.  Improved Water Resources Management 
 
32.  The Project will support improved irrigation, drainage, and water resources management 
from the basin to the on-farm level. The Project will also support a basin and irrigation and 
drainage management institutional optimization and coordination study to prepare a plan and 
capacity development program to improve water use efficiency and productivity for inter-farm 
irrigation and drainage in the Fergana Valley. The study will (i) analyze existing institutional and 
organization structures of BISAs, ISA, MCA, Department of Pump Station Operations (DPSO), 
WUAs,  local  government,  and  other  relevant  stakeholders;  (ii)  analyze  their  existing 
management  rules,  regulations,  procedures,  and  systems  to  identify  bottlenecks  and 
inefficiencies for irrigation, drainage, and water management; (iii) analyze coordination between 
water management stakeholders; (iv) develop options and a plan to improve (a) the institutional 
and organization structures, (b) management and operational procedures and systems,21 and

3.  Project Management 
 
35.  The  Project  will  provide  implementation  support  to  the  project  management  office

D.  Special Features 
 
36.  The Project represents a shift from previous assistance to Uzbekistan in that its focus is 
on the R&U of pumps and inter-farm canals and structures and associated water management. 
The R&U of irrigation infrastructure will introduce more efficient pumps to improve both water 
use and energy efficiency. The Project explicitly recognizes Uzbekistan’s need to improve water 
use efficiency and productivity, and uses a comprehensive approach to implement improved 
water management measures at the (i) overall basin level with BISAs; (ii) inter-farm level 
through improved water management and operations of the canal commands and pumps of the 
subprojects; and (iii) on-farm level through the training of WUAs to manage the on-farm systems 
more effectively. It will strengthen integration of operations between inter- and on-farm systems.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Project Benefits 
 
58.  Project benefits include (i) reduced production losses, (ii) increased energy efficiency, 
(iii) improved water management, (iv) decreased land degradation caused by soil salinity and 
waterlogging,  (v)  increased  irrigation  efficiency,  (vi)  enhanced  farm  productivity  through 
increased yields and cropping intensity, and (vii) increased rural livelihoods. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Analysis 
 
1.  Economic Analysis 
 
59.  A  financial and  economic  analysis  was  carried  out  for the  two  subprojects  and  an 
economic analysis was carried for the Project as a whole. For the economic analyses, a shadow 
exchange rate of SUM1,320 to $1.00 was used. Costs are expressed in constant 2008 prices. 
Economic values for cotton, wheat, maize, and fertilizer were calculated using border parity 
prices.  A  shadow  wage  rate  conversion  factor  of  0.85  is  used  because  of  local 
underemployment. Appendix 10 provides a Summary Financial and Economic Analysis while 
the detailed economic and financial information is presented in Supplementary Appendix F, and 
Supplementary Appendix G provides the detailed cost tables. 
 
60.  Economic Benefits. The total R&U costs of the Narpay subproject are estimated at 
$13.05 million, including contingencies. The R&U of the eight pumps and motors contributes 
78% to the cost while R&U of the irrigation network is estimated to cost only 10% of total cost. 
The  R&U  costs  for  the  Besharyk  subproject are  higher,  at  a  cost of  $24.233 million  with 
contingencies. Replacement of the pumps, repair of the rising main, and widening of the intake 
channel  contribute  57%  of  costs  while  expansion  of  the  delivery  system  contributes  20%. 
Drainage needs are much greater in Besharyk and comprise nearly 5% of the R&U costs. 
 
61.  The  main  project  benefit  is  sustained  and  improved  agricultural  productivity.25  The 
benefits  include  an  increase  in  crop  yield  of  5%,  a  20%  efficiency  improvement  in  pump 
operation, and a 10% improvement in water use efficiency. The Narpay subproject economic 
internal rate of return (EIRR) is 15.4%. The Besharyk subproject has an EIRR of 13.4%. 
Besharyk is more sensitive than Narpay, and both are most robust with regard to increases in 
electricity, O&M, or initial capital costs. Both have some sensitivity to changes in net benefits or 
wheat and cotton prices. The analysis is based on state-mandated cropping patterns, and 
returns will improve as policies liberalize and farmers can grow more wheat or other crops with

C.  Environmental and Social Safeguards 
 
1.  Environment 
 
63.  The Project falls under category B for environment. Initial environmental examinations 
(IEE)  were  prepared  for  each  subproject.  The  Project  is  unlikely  to  cause  any  significant 
environmental impacts and will be beneficial because of drainage improvements. Potential 
impacts, mitigation measures, and reporting requirements are presented in the environmental 
mitigation  and  monitoring  plan  (EMP)  prepared  for  each  subproject.  The  EMP  defines 
institutional responsibilities and provides cost estimates. The monitoring program under the 
EMP of the subprojects includes provisions for regular sampling of the water quality from the 
irrigation pump intakes and the drainage outlet from each WUA area. Individual designs for 
infrastructure R&U are to be submitted to the SCNP for review. These designs should include a 
site-specific environmental mitigation plan that is based on generic guidelines provided in the 
IEE, which sets out environmental safeguards and mitigation measures to be incorporated in 
tender documentation for design and works contracts. The project site supervisors and the PMO 
will monitor compliance with these safeguards and mitigation measures, which will be subject to 
inspection by the SCNP. An environmental assessment and review procedure (EARP) was 
prepared to provide guidance for preparation of IEEs and EMPs to ensure compliance with ADB 
policies and Uzbek law. The IEEs, EARP, and summary IEEs are in Supplementary Appendix 
H.  
 
  2.  Involuntary Resettlement 
 
64.  The Project will involve R&U of existing pump stations, inter-farm irrigation canals, and 
drainage systems. It is anticipated that all R&U works will be within the boundaries of the 
Government’s right-of-way for existing structures, canals, and drains. Rehabilitation activities, 
such as replacement of pumps and rehabilitation of canals, will be phased to ensure there is no 
disruption to the on-farm irrigation water supply. Civil works implementation will be scheduled 
during the non-vegetation season to minimize the risk of disruption. It is not anticipated that any 
land acquisition or permanent displacement will take place. Any impact would be associated 
with construction and should be limited in its scope and duration. A resettlement framework with 
compensation matrix has been prepared and agreed with the Government, consistent with 
ADB’s policy for sector projects, to address any impact, should it occur. Appendix 12 provides a 
summary and Supplementary Appendix I provides more detailed resettlement information.

D.  Community Participation and Gender 
 
  1.  Participation 
 
66.  The Project has been prepared in consultation with stakeholders including MAWR staff, 
district  agricultural  departments,  WUAs,  pump  operators,  private  farmers,  dekhan  farmers,

during the course of project implementation to ensure involvement of WUA members and 
farmers in the planning of the R&U works, especially for inter-farm canals and drains. 
 
  2.  Gender 
 
67.  More than 50% of the population in Uzbekistan is women, and 64% of the population 
lives in rural areas. Women’s share in the economically active population is 48%. The Project 
will not have an adverse impact on women and girls and will be gender-neutral. (Appendix 13 
and Supplementary Appendix J). The project design was developed to (i) include a gender 
specialist in the PMO; (ii) set out an information campaign that clearly identifies the role of 
women in the Project; (iii) establish and train monitoring groups; and (iv) disaggregate key input, 
output, and outcome indicators by gender. 
 
E.  Project Risks and Sustainability 
 
68.  The design and monitoring framework (Appendix 2) sets out a comprehensive list of 
risks and assumptions for the Project. 
 
69.  Sustaining  O&M  of  the  R&U  of  irrigation  and  drainage  systems  is  a  key  risk  to 
achievement of the outcome and impact. Government budget allocations will be monitored to 
assure adequate and timely provision of budgetary funds.  
 
70.  Delays in the implementation of civil works, caused by slow procurement procedures at 
the government level, is another risk. To avoid serious delays, especially at the start-up stage, 
advance action will be undertaken on staff recruitment.  
 
71.  Other risks include macroeconomic shocks and commodity price instability.

SECTOR AND SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Sector Overview 
 
1.  Economy and Agriculture. Uzbekistan had an estimated per capita gross domestic 
product (GDP) of about $650 in 2006. GDP growth rates have increased from 3.8%–4.0% 
during 2000–2003 to an annual average of over 7.0% during 2004–20061 and 9.5% in 2007.2 
Agriculture growth has fluctuated from 3.1% in 2000, to 10.1% in 2004 to 5.6% in 2007. It is 
expected to decline to 4%–5% over the next 3 years. The share of agriculture in GDP has also 
declined from 30.1% in 2000 to 24.1% in 2006 (footnote 1). Despite this relative decline in 
growth, agriculture remains an important sector in the economy, accounting for 70% of domestic 
trade, 35%–40% of industrial output (about 7.8% of GDP), about 25% of export earnings, and 
33% of national employment. However, while poverty declined from 27.5% in 2001 to 25.8% in 
2005, poverty reduction in rural areas declined less than in urban areas. About 64% of the 
population lives in rural areas, which are either directly or indirectly reliant on agriculture. Rural 
communities account for more than 70% of the poor in Uzbekistan. This underscores the 
importance of improving rural livelihoods through increased agricultural productivity. 
 
2.  Water Resources, Irrigation, and Drainage. Uzbekistan is an arid country and has 
average rainfall of 264 millimeters (mm), from a low 97 mm in the northwest to 425 mm in the 
mountainous areas. The country lies fully within the Amu Darya river basin that covers 86.5% of 
the land, and the Syr Darya river basin that covers 13.5% of the land. These rivers and their 
tributaries provide all the water resources to support irrigated agriculture. However, the water 
they supply varies considerably on a seasonal basis and with regard to the location in the 
country, with many areas suffering extreme water scarcity. Because of Uzbekistan’s arid climate 
and the variability in availability of water resources, almost all agriculture has always been 
dependent  on  irrigation.  Irrigation  takes  place  on  90%  of  the  farmed  arable  land  and  is 
responsible for nearly all agricultural production. It consumes 85% of all water resources and 
requires about 57 cubic kilometers (km3) annually. Accordingly, development and management 
of irrigation and drainage infrastructure and improved water management are key government 
priorities. 
 
3.   Uzbekistan has 4.3 million hectares (ha) of irrigated land (2.35 million ha in the Amu 
Darya river basin and 1.95 million ha in the Syr Darya river basin). This is over 40% of all 
irrigation in Central Asia, and nearly double that of Kazakhstan, which ranks next in terms of 
irrigated area. In 1960, Uzbekistan had less than 2.6 million ha, yet by 1990, the Soviet Union 
had expanded irrigation to its current area. This was mainly for intensive cotton production. The 
rapid development of intensive irrigated agriculture throughout Central Asia during this period is 
largely responsible for desiccation of the Aral Sea and the associated environmental, social, and 
economic disaster. However, the massive investment economically transformed many areas in 
Uzbekistan  and  improved  the  livelihoods  of  rural  communities  who  are  now  completely 
dependent on the flow of irrigation water. 
 
4.  To support this vast irrigated area, Uzbekistan has an extensive network of irrigation and 
drainage infrastructure divided into two types: (i) inter-farm, and (ii) and on-farm systems. The 
inter-farm system comprises the large intake structures for water irrigation supply, and the main 
and distributary canals that convey water to the farm level outlets as well as the large collector

5.  Agriculture and Farming Systems. Cotton is the priority crop grown, and Uzbekistan is 
the world’s sixth largest producer. Cotton received extensive and intensive development under 
the Soviet Union. Since Uzbekistan’s independence in 1992, wheat self-sufficiency also became 
a strategic priority of the Government, and it was first achieved in 1997. Wheat and cotton 
comprise the vast majority of agricultural production, with cotton grown on about 41% of the 
irrigated area and wheat on 42% of the irrigated area. 
 
6.  Irrigated farm production is based on three types of farms: (i) shirkat farms, which were 
created  from  Soviet  collective  farms;  (ii)  private  farms;  and  (iii)  dekhan  (small  inheritable 
household  plot  [0.15–0.35  hectares]  free  from  Government  quotas  for  crop  selection  and 
marketing) farms. The shirkats were formed during the 1990s as a reform of the former state 
farms, but their operation was still based on collective ownership of the farm assets, and their 
performance  was  poor.  As  a  remedy,  the  Government  increased  efforts  to  “privatize”  the 
shirkats by breaking them into smaller parcels and selling them for management and operation 
by individuals. By 2004, 125,000 private farms had been established on over 2.3 million ha, and 
today all of the shirkats have been eliminated and converted to private farms.  
 
7.  While many of the shirkats have been privatized to individuals, is the private farms are 
still controlled by the Government, which dictates the production and marketing of cotton and 
wheat. Farmers are subject to quotas to grow large areas of cotton and wheat with subsidized 
credits and inputs. They are also required to sell 50% of the wheat and cotton harvest to the 
Government below world market prices. The Government controls a significant portion of the 
value chain for these crops. The production quotas tied to cotton and wheat also require 
intensive water use and contribute to salinization and land degradation. In addition, land use 
contracts are often not registered or recognized, so local authorities can evict farmers who do 
not meet production quotas, and the title of the land is not transferable to another user. This 
situation limits incentives for private productivity investments and limits credit availability since 
farms are not viable collateral. The wheat and cotton cropping rotation does not allow for 
periodic fallowing of land or rotation with fodder or other crops to replenish soil nutrients and 
absorb salts. Dekhan farms are generally quite small fringe holdings, and their land rights are 
clearly established to private individuals, which allow secure long-term possession and free 
cropping patterns. There are about 4 million–5 million of these small dekhan farms, and they 
produce  nearly  one-fifth  of  the  country’s  grains,  nearly  all  of  the  horticulture,  and  provide 
important cash income for farmers.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems, Opportunities, and Lessons 
 
8.  Irrigation  and  Drainage  Needs.  During  the  time  of  the  former  Soviet  Union,  new 
infrastructure  was  constructed  and  existing  infrastructure  improved,  but  its  condition  has 
deteriorated since independence. The state’s share in agricultural investment has declined, from 
27% in 1991 to 8% in 2001. From 1995 to 2002, government funding for the water sector 
dropped from 2.9% to 1.8% of GDP—a 60% decrease. At the same time, resources for capital 
investment in the water sector declined from 0.9% to 0.6% of GDP, reducing funds for operation 
and maintenance (O&M) by a third. Currently, it is estimated that deferred capital and O&M 
expenditures are about 40% of the irrigation and drainage asset value. 
 
9.  The  irrigation  and  drainage  system  needs  substantial  rehabilitation  and  upgrading 
(R&U), and major irrigation structures are at risk of failure that would cause significant losses in 
agricultural production. The following R&U needs have been identified throughout the country (i) 
total reconstruction of 32% of the main and inter-farm canals, and repair of 24% of them; (ii) 
rebuilding of 42% of the on-farm irrigation network, and repairs for 17%; (iii) replacement and 
modernization of the mechanical equipment of 18 of the 42 large-intake structures (about 10–
300 cubic meters per second [m3/sec]) and reconstruction of 5; (iv) 16 of the 27 inspected 
reservoirs are nonfunctional or threatened with sedimentation; (v) 19,000 km of on-farm drains 
need de-silting, and 11,500 km of open and subsurface drains need reconstruction or repair; 
and (vi) only about 50% of the subsurface horizontal drainage systems are operational. To 
rectify this situation will require sustained R&U investment into the system, and new modalities 
for O&M are required to prevent further deterioration and to ensure that investment returns are 
sustainable following system R&U. 
 
10.  Pumped irrigation provides water to about half the irrigated area in Uzbekistan and 
poses unique challenges. It includes the three massive irrigation pump cascades systems from 
the Amu Darya River that include the Amu Bukhara, Karshi, and Amu Zhang systems. Together, 
the systems irrigate over 800,000 ha of land, and entire regions with numerous towns and 
villages and millions of people are dependent on their continued operation. Amu Zhang is 
currently being rehabilitated through ADB support although the other two large cascades also 
need urgent rehabilitation.3 Other smaller yet still substantial pumped irrigation facilities are 
located throughout all the gravity irrigation networks, with schemes in the range of 5,000–10,000 
ha  reliant  on  pumps  being  quite  common.  Almost  all  irrigation  and  drainage  pumps  in 
Uzbekistan are operating beyond their design life and adequate resources have been lacking for 
their  maintenance  since  independence.  Many  pumps  are  starting  to  fail,  and  without 
intervention, many more are likely to fail soon. Of the 76 very large pumping facilities with 
capacities greater than 100 m3/sec, 60 require immediate rehabilitation. In addition, 400 of the 
1,000  smaller  pumped  systems,  with  capacities  of  10  m3/sec  or  less  need  immediate 
rehabilitation or replacement. Energy for pumped irrigation accounts for 70% of the annual O&M 
budget of the Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources (MAWR), and consumes 20% of 
Uzbekistan’s electricity. Substantial investment is needed for R&U of the pumped systems since 
their failure would eliminate a significant portion of irrigated areas and substantially reduce the 
livelihoods of rural communities farming in these systems. Opportunities also exist to increase 
the  efficiency  of  smaller  pumped  extension  systems  through  new  pump  technology,  more 
demand-responsive operating regimes, and improved irrigation techniques.

11.  The state of irrigation and drainage infrastructure, combined with current irrigation and 
water resources management practices, result in generally low agricultural productivity. Average 
water  withdrawal  for  irrigation  is  14,000  cubic  meters  (m3)  per  ha,  compared  with               
9,000–10,000 m3 in countries with similar climates. Irrigation efficiency nationwide is only about 
40%. The result is wasted water, overloaded drainage systems, and worsening land salinization. 
MAWR estimates that more than 20,000 ha of land goes out of production each year because of 
salinity caused by poor water management and inadequate drainage. The salinity affects cotton 
yields, which decline by 20%–30% on slightly salinized land, and up to 80% on highly salinized 
land.  Some  degree  of  salinization  and  waterlogging  affects  47%  of  all  irrigated  land. 4  
Productivity in irrigated agriculture dropped by 15% in the immediate post-Soviet era but has 
now recovered slightly. However, yields are still lower than they should be, with an average of 
2.25 tons per ha for cotton and 4.2 tons per ha for wheat. 
 
12.  Transboundary Water Resources Management. The total runoff for water resources 
generated in Uzbekistan is about 11.5 km3 per year while the total demand for irrigation is about 
57 km3. The rest of the required flow comes from upstream counties in the Amu Darya and Syr 
Darya rivers. During the time of the former Soviet Union, interstate allocations were centrally 
managed to support irrigation in the summer, and upstream countries were supplied with energy 
during the winter months. In 1992, following the collapse of the Soviet Union and in response to 
the Aral Sea crisis, the Central Asian republics5 established the Interstate Commission for 
Water Coordination (ICWC) to oversee water allocation. Although there are no permanent 
water-sharing  agreements,  water  allocation  is  decided  twice  a  year  under  the  ICWC  and 
managed by the basin water management organizations for the Syr Darya and Amu Darya 
under the ICWC.6 
 
13.  Institutional  Framework  for  Irrigation  and  Drainage.  The  legal  and  regulatory 
framework for the irrigation and drainage in Uzbekistan is mainly derived from the Law on Water 
and  Water  Use,  1993,  that  addresses  water  rights  and  allocation,  O&M  of  irrigation  and 
drainage systems, and resolution of water disputes. The Law on Water and Water Use, 1993, 
also gives MAWR overall responsibility for water resources. Within MAWR, the Directorate for 
Water Management (DWM) is the primary organization responsible for the development, O&M, 
and management of irrigation and drainage infrastructure. 
 
14.  The responsibilities of DWM include the following: (i) measure and report water use on 
the irrigation and drainage system; (ii) analyze forecasts of water supply and demand, work out 
water balances, and determine water withdrawal limits for river basins and water use within the 
basin; (iii) provide permits for water use and establish water allocations; (iv) annually monitor 
the ameliorative condition of irrigated land and register the ameliorative categories of land 
(degrees  of  salinization);  (v)  propose  measures  to improve  the  condition  and  operation  of 
irrigation  and  drainage  systems  and  prevent  land  degradation;  (vi)  introduce  innovative 
technologies  and  create  long-term  plans  for  increasing  water  productivity;  (vii)  conduct 
investment policy; (viii) assess feasibility of developing new irrigation areas and reconstruction 
of existing irrigation systems; (ix) oversee project design, and research and manage civil works 
for  irrigation  and  drainage  systems;  and  (x)  approve  projects  related  to  developing  and 
managing irrigation and drainage systems.

15.  The decree of the Cabinet of Ministers7 reorganized MAWR from a provincial and district 
administrative basis to a water basin principle, in which all river basins and subbasins are 
managed by basin irrigation system administrations (BISAs) under DWM.8 Ten BISAs have 
been formed throughout the country. The territory of each BISA is organized into main canal 
administrations  (MCAs)  and  irrigation  system  administrations  (ISAs).  MCAs  and  ISAs  are 
structured  according  to  sections  of  the  canal  system  and  the  main  diversion  structures. 
According to the charters of BISAs, MCAs, and ISAs, their roles and responsibilities in O&M are 
similar, applied at their respective levels of the irrigation and drainage system and include the 
following: (i) compile and implement plans for preventive maintenance and capital development; 
(ii) MCAs reach agreements with ISAs and pump stations for water delivery within the allocation 
limits set by the BISA; (iii) ISAs conclude and execute agreements for water delivery from MCAs 
and pump stations and to water users’ associations (WUAs); (iv) provide timely water supply to 
farmers; (v) equip infrastructure with water-measuring devices and measure and report water 
deliveries  and  withdrawals  on  the  system;  (vi)  enforce  the  observance  of  water-related 
legislation and water withdrawal limits; (vii) enforce water distribution; and (viii) aid in conducting 
the state water cadastre and making annual estimates of the availability of irrigated land within 
the  service  area.  Although  the  creation  of  BISAs  was  a  substantial  improvement  for 
management of water resources and irrigation and drainage management practice, and BISAs 
have a legacy of Soviet engineering expertise, BISAs would benefit from exposure to advanced 
irrigation and water management methods to help them manage water more effectively. 
 
16.  The  Department  of  Pump  Stations,  Energy,  and  Communications  (DPSEC)  is 
responsible  for  the  main  and  inter-farm  pump  stations  but  was  not  a  part  of  the  MAWR 
reorganization to the BISA framework in 2003. At the national level, DPSEC is under MAWR but 
DPSEC has branch offices in each province, directly financed from MAWR—not through BISAs. 
DPSEC has its own administrative structure and management, and in addition to pumps, it is 
responsible for providing communications to all water management organizations, including 
BISAs. DPSEC is also responsible for O&M of some on-farm pump stations because new 
WUAs cannot afford to keep the pumps running and local authorities often force DPSEC take on 
the responsibility. 
 
17.  In  addition  to  management  of  the  surface  and  pump  irrigation  systems,  MAWR  is 
responsible for O&M for drainage. At the province level, MAWR has a branch office of the 
Department of Land Reclamation, the Hydrogeological Ameliorative Expedition (HAE), which is 
directly financed from central Government. HAE is supposed to fall within the BISA framework, 
according to establishing legislation. However, the BISA has no direct mandate that specifically 
relates to the responsibilities for groundwater, drainage, and reclamation, so the relationship is 
one more of close cooperation than direct control. HAE has its own administrative structure and 
management and is responsible for (i) maintenance and rehabilitation of the main and inter-farm 
drainage system (including drainage pumping stations) in each BISA, (ii) assessment of the 
condition of drainage systems, and (iii) monitoring water table levels as well as soil and water 
salinity levels. Normally, if a WUA wants help from HAE for cleaning or repair of any part of the 
on-farm drainage network, the cost is paid by the WUA to HAE. In 2008, the Government 
approved $75 million for an amelioration fund from the land tax to improve drainage. Under this 
fund, both the inter-farm and on-farm drainage networks will be rehabilitated using government 
funds.

18.  Water Users’ Associations. With the conversion of the shirkats to private farms, the 
former  state-supported  O&M  and  management  of  the  on-farm  irrigation  and  drainage 
infrastructure has been eliminated, and WUAs have been established in their place. By law, 
WUAs have responsibility for the on-farm system and are obligated to observe water allocation 
limits, maintain infrastructure, take measures to reduce land salinization, observe sustainable 
crop rotations, adopt water-saving technologies, and endeavor to increase water productivity. 
WUAs  are  forbidden  to  operate  inter-farm  infrastructure  for  the  purpose  of  increasing  or 
decreasing water supply. The experience with WUAs in Uzbekistan is limited and variable. 
Although they have been established in most cases, there is no institutionalized program within 
MAWR that provides for their training or resources to support their establishment, and they have 
developed under various models. They also lack equipment since much of the equipment that 
was supposed to be transferred to them from the shirkats was sold off prior to transfer or is not 
functional. WUA sizes vary, with some entire districts put under one WUA. Responsibilities also 
vary depending on the type and complexity of system that has been transferred. Financial 
sustainability is also difficult since WUA membership fees, along with the rate of collection from 
farmers. The WUAs also have limited options in their ability to collect payment. The Swiss 
Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC) has provided training and support for some 
WUAs. This has significantly improved their performance with regard to water management and 
system O&M, and provides experience from which to scale up a broader training effort. WUAs 
play a vital role in improving the productivity of irrigated agriculture and water management, yet 
they require greater support to fulfill this mandate more effectively. 
 
19.  Water Management. Given the importance of irrigation and the reliance of Uzbekistan 
on water coming across its borders, effective water management is essential within the country. 
Improving the technical competence of the BISAs, MCAs, and ISAs can improve water use 
efficiency and productivity. Capacity building for water management should complement any 
inter-farm investment in infrastructure to help realize its full potential. The inter-farm irrigation 
system would also benefit from improved water monitoring, measurement, and more effective 
management. Potential exists to improve water use efficiency by upgrading existing structures 
and controls through new operational procedures, automation, and supervisory control and data 
acquisition  systems.  MAWR  has  already  seen  positive  benefits  from  limited  use  of  these 
measures in the Fergana Valley and in the Zarafshan river basin under programs by the United 
States Agency for International Development and SDC. More comprehensive application of 
these  technologies,  with  associated  training  for  BISAs,  can  further  improve  water  use 
efficiencies.  
 
20.  Efficiency gains can be achieved through better planning and integration of ISA staff 
operating the inter-farm canals and structures, and WUA staff operating on-farm canals, to 
optimize water deliveries. Especially in the pump systems, which have greater flexibility and can 
be more demand-responsive, better communication and coordination between WUAs and ISA 
staff  could  yield  substantial  benefits.  As  noted,  on-farm  water  management  is  under  the 
supervision of the WUAs, which need capacity development for improved water management. 
In cases where training has been provided combined with measurement structures in the on-
farm canals, savings of 10%–20% have been realized along with productivity improvements. All 
levels of irrigation in Uzbekistan can be made more efficient with improved water management.

areas. The income of women in the Narpay subproject area reflects gender inequalities indicated by the following: (i) 
the economic activity of women is low, with 44% of women in employable age but only about 30% employed; (ii) 54% 
of  working  women are employed in the nonagricultural  sector, mainly in healthcare and education; (iii) in the 
nonagricultural sector, women occupy lower-paid positions; (iv) the share of entrepreneurs among women is almost 3 
times smaller than that of men; (v) women are paid 50%–80% of male wages; (vi) women have less access to rural 
financial services; and (vii) women are generally overburdened with domestic work and household responsibilities. 
Existing gender stereotypes set household duties as a priority for women, which do not let them achieve full and 
effective employment. Women’s duties include cooking, laundering, house cleaning, taking care of children and elderly 
family members, working on the garden plot, looking after livestock and poultry, and delivering water for drinking and

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT FRAMEWORK 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  This summary presents the highlights of the land acquisition and resettlement framework 
(LARF) prepared for the Water Resources Management Sector Project in Uzbekistan. The 
LARF outlines the objectives, policy principles, land acquisition and processing requirements, 
compensation, and other assistance measures for affected persons. The LARF will serve as 
guide to prepare any required land acquisition and resettlement plan (LARP) for subprojects 
under the Project. The document is based on national laws, the country’s 1998 Land Code and 
related resolutions of cabinet ministers as well as the Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995) 
and related policies of Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
 
B.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement Processing Requirements 
 
2.  Consistent with ADB’s guidelines, all proposed subprojects will be screened based on 
the following categories of impacts: (i) a full LARP is required under category A subproject if 
200 or more people will be physically displaced from housing or lose 10% or more of their 
productive (income-generating) assets; (ii) a short LARP will be prepared for category B if fewer 
than 200 people will be physically displaced from housing or lose less than 10% of their 
productive (income-generating) assets; and (iii) no LARP is required for category C if the 
subproject  does  not  require  temporary  or  permanent  land  acquisition  and/or  there  are  no 
resettlement impacts. However, a due diligence report will be prepared to indicate why the 
component has been categorized as C.1 Procedures for the preparation of the LARP are 
prescribed in the LARF. However, in accordance with selection criteria for the Project and 
consistent with the practice of the State Committee on Land Resources, Geodesy, Cartography 
and State Cadastre (SCLRGCSC), only category B and category C subprojects will be funded 
under the Project.  
 
C.  Resettlement Framework and Policy 
 
3.  The  relevant  laws  in  Uzbekistan  and  ADB’s  Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy 
requirements were compared to assess their consistency. To fill their gaps and satisfy ADB’s 
policy requirements, the following core involuntary resettlement principles were adopted for the 
Project: (i) temporary and permanent acquisition of lands will be minimized to avoid significant 
losses on farm revenues; (ii) where displacement cannot be avoided, the affected persons will 
be provided assistance to at least maintain or improve their pre-subproject living standards, 
income earning capacity, and production levels; (iii) stakeholders in the subproject locality will 
be  systematically  informed  and  properly  consulted  (a)  to  identify  the  possible  alternative 
subproject designs to avoid or minimize the adverse impacts of land acquisition; (b) to disclose 
those  who  are  eligible  to  receive  compensation,  entitlements,  and  the  special  assistance 
measures; and (c) for the preparation and disclosures of LARPs to affected persons and others; 
(iv) all affected persons will be properly identified, recorded, and disaggregated by gender in a 
census instrument in which the cut-off date for their eligibility is the last day of the survey in the 
subproject area, and they will be notified in advance when the land for subprojects will be 
acquired; (v) lack of certificate of land use right and/or certificate of permanent ownership of 
land should not deprive the affected persons from receiving compensation, entitlement, and 
rehabilitation measures; (vi) special assistance measures will be incorporated in the LARP

Uzbekistan for Preparing the Water Resources Management Sector Project. Manila.

58  Appendix 12 
 
implementation process to protect the socially and economically vulnerable groups that may be 
affected2 and improve their standard of living; (vii) effective mechanisms for arbitration of 
complaints  and  grievances  will  be  provided  during  LARP  implementation;  (viii)  institutional 
arrangements  and  resources  will  be  in  place  for  consultation,  liaison,  land  acquisition, 
resettlement, and monitoring to ensure the effective implementation of land acquisition and 
resettlement plan prior to commencement of the subproject; and (ix) prior to displacement, the 
provision for replacement land, compensation to affected properties, and other resettlement 
assistance should have been completed and extended before the award of the civil works 
contract. Based on the preceding principles, the compensation and entitlements of affected 
persons are summarized in the entitlement matrix in Table A12.1. 
 
4.  All permanently affected lands of the farmers shall be provided with replacement lands. 
Other  affected  properties  will  be  compensated  based  on  replacement  cost.  Eligibility  for 
compensation will be limited by a cut-off date to be established for each subproject on the 
starting day of the census and impact assessment. The affected persons who have established 
their  structures  within  the  subproject  sites  after  the  cut-off  date  are  not  eligible  for 
compensation. However, they will be given sufficient advance notice to dismantle the structures 
and vacate the affected premises prior to project implementation. Their dismantled structures 
will not be confiscated, and they will not pay any fine or sanction. Forced eviction will only be 
used after all avenues for amicable resolution to vacate the subproject premises have been 
exhausted. Women and vulnerable groups will be given particular attention for assistance in the 
preparation and implementation of LARPs. 
 
D.  Public Participation, Documents Disclosure, and Grievance Redress 
 
5.  The  Project  is  designed  for  stakeholders’  participation  during  LARP  preparation. 
Province, district, and village officials will be informed and their assistance will be solicited for 
the conduct of the inventory of affected assets and the census of affected persons. Prior to the 
finalization of the LARP, it will be translated into the Uzbek language so that affected persons 
will  be  thoroughly  informed  and  validate  their  preferences  for  compensation  and/or  other 
resettlement  assistance,  including  their  opinions  on  compensation  rates.  The  meeting  with 
affected persons will be recorded in the minutes of the consultation. The LARF and the LARPs 
will be translated into the Uzbek language for disclosure to affected persons, and copies will 
also be made available at the concerned districts and villages. The English versions of the 
LARF and LARPs will be endorsed by the Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources (MAWR) 
to ADB for posting on the ADB website.  
 
6.  Grievances  or  complaints  from  affected  persons  will  be  solved  in  a  timely  and 
satisfactory  manner.  The  project  management  office  (PMO)  for  the  Project  will  mobilize 
grievance and redress committees (GRCs) whose members will comprise PMO representatives, 
private  farmers,  and  owners  of  dekhan  farms  (small  inheritable  household  plot  [0.15–0.35 
hectares] free in crop selection and marketing) who are not necessarily affected persons, and 
representatives  from  the  group  of  affected  persons  themselves.  Women  will  be  invited  as 
members. Any grievance or complaint will be first brought to the attention of the GRC. The GRC 
will meet to determine the merit of each grievance, and resolve it within 15 days upon receipt of 
the complaint. If not satisfied with the GRC decision, the affected person can bring his or her 
complaint to the district department of SCLRGCSC, or to its province department, where each 
department is given 15 days to resolve the case. The affected person can file the grievance or

complaint to the judicial court if he or she is still unsatisfied with the decision of the SCLRGCSC. 
The term of each GRC will expire upon the satisfactory completion of land acquisitions and 
payment of compensation and entitlement to affected persons. 
 
E.  Institutional Arrangements 
 
7.  MAWR  is  the  Executing  Agency.  It  will  establish  the  PMO,  which  will  oversee 
implementation of the LARF and LARPs. The PMO will be assisted by a (i) national resettlement 
specialist to assist in LARP planning, preparation and implementation, internal monitoring and 
evaluation  (M&E);  (ii)  a  nongovernment  organization  to  provide  on-site  LARP  preparation 
assistance for surveys, information gathering, and consultations with affected persons and the 
public in general; and (iii) an external monitoring agent to conduct periodic M&E and third-party 
validation of LARP implementation activities. 
 
8.  The PMO will also solicit the assistance from the government administration of provinces 
and districts and the SCLRGCSC subdivisions at the province and district levels as well as the 
concerned parties. The concerned parties will be composed of representatives of farmers, 
owners of dekhan farms and the neighboring landowners and users, including the affected 
persons. They will serve as witness to the marking of lands and jointly issue the certificate of 
land  markings  to  PMO.  The  certificate  will  be  included  as  part  of  the  preparation  of  the 
instruction  on  land  allocation.  Table  A12.2  summarizes  the  phasing  of  the  involvement  of 
concerned project personnel and institutions in LARP preparation and implementation. All the 
concerned staff of PMO, MAWR, and the local nongovernment organization involved in LARP 
activities will undergo an orientation and training on ADB resettlement policy and management. 
The  orientation  and  training  will  be  conducted  by  the  resettlement  specialist  (technical 
assistance consultant). 
 
F.  Resettlement Budget and Financing 
 
9.  Funds  will  be  provided  for  all  LARPs.  Provisions  will  cover  the  compensation, 
assistance,  other  allowances  to  affected  persons,  implementing  costs,  and  contingency 
allowance  for  unforeseen  expenses  and  for  cushioning  the  effect  of  inflation.  MAWR  will 
approve the budgets and facilitate the release of funds for implementing the LARP. The LARPs 
will describe the flow of funds including the accounting systems, as these are part of the overall 
project development expenditures for which ADB, through the external monitoring agent, will 
monitor the disbursements for LARPs. 
 
G.  Monitoring and Evaluation 
 
10.  Internal and external monitoring will be conducted during LARP implementation. The 
PMO, assisted by the local NGO and resettlement specialist, will be responsible for internal 
monitoring. Internal monitoring will cover activities related to (i) information campaigns and 
consultation  with  affected  persons;  (ii)  status  of  land  acquisition  and  payments  on  land 
compensation; (iii) compensation for affected structures and other assets; (iv) relocation of 
affected persons; (v) payments for loss of incomes; (vi) selection and distribution of replacement 
land areas; and (vii) income restoration activities. Related information will be collected from the 
field  and  reported  monthly  to  the  PMO  to  assess  the  progress  and  results  of  LARP 
implementation, and to adjust the work program, if necessary. The monthly reports will be 
consolidated every quarter and be a part of quarterly reporting by the PMO to ADB. 
 
11.  External monitoring will be the responsibility of the external monitoring agent that will be 
hired by the PMO at the early stage of LARP implementation. The external monitoring agent will

60  Appendix 12 
 
conduct external monitoring in two phases: (i) compliance monitoring, and (ii) social impact 
evaluation. Compliance monitoring will involve the assessment LARP implementation that will 
be the basis of MAWR to request a “no objection” from ADB for the award of civil works 
contract. The social impact evaluation will cover the post-resettlement situations of vulnerable 
groups like households headed by women, disabled and/or elderly, and families living below the 
poverty threshold. The evaluation will also describe the outstanding future issues that are 
required to bring resettlement into compliance with ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy, 
government policies, and further mitigation measures needed to meet the needs of affected 
persons or households perceiving themselves to be worse off as the result of resettlement. It will

land acquisition and resettlement. The PMO and ADB will prepare the terms of reference for the 
external  monitoring  agent  that  will  be  chosen  among  local  consultants  or  nongovernment 
organizations, prior to LARP implementation.
